title: Swimming Pool Volume Calculator

seo.title: Pool Volume Calculator | Calculate Water Capacity in Gallons & Liters
seo.description: Calculate the volume of your swimming pool in gallons or liters. Supports rectangular, round, and oval pools. Easily determine how much water your pool holds for chemical dosing, refilling, or maintenance.

inputs.label: Pool Shape
inputs.hint: Select the shape of your swimming pool.

inputs.label: Length
inputs.hint: Enter the length of your pool.

inputs.label: Width
inputs.hint: Enter the width of your pool.

inputs.label: Diameter
inputs.hint: Enter the diameter of your round pool.

inputs.label: Average Depth
inputs.hint: Enter the average depth of your pool. If sloped, calculate (shallowest + deepest) / 2.

inputs.label: Input Units
inputs.hint: Select the unit for your input measurements.

formula:
The calculator first converts all input dimensions to a base unit (e.g., feet or meters). Then, it applies the appropriate geometric formula based on the selected pool shape to calculate the volume in cubic units:
- Rectangular: Length × Width × Average Depth
- Round: π × (Diameter / 2)² × Average Depth
- Oval: π × (Length / 2) × (Width / 2) × Average Depth
Finally, the cubic volume is converted into gallons (1 ft³ = 7.48052 US gallons) and liters (1 ft³ = 28.3168 liters).

faq.question: How do I calculate the volume of a rectangular pool?
faq.answer: To calculate the volume of a rectangular or square pool, multiply its length by its width by its average depth. Ensure all measurements are in the same unit before multiplying.

faq.question: What is the formula for a round pool's volume?
faq.answer: For a round pool, the volume formula is π (pi, approximately 3.14159) multiplied by the square of the radius (half the diameter) multiplied by the average depth: Volume = π × (Radius)² × Average Depth.

faq.question: How do I find the average depth if my pool has a sloped bottom?
faq.answer: If your pool has a sloped bottom (e.g., a shallow end of 3 ft and a deep end of 6 ft), calculate the average depth by adding the shallowest depth to the deepest depth and dividing by two: Average Depth = (Shallowest Depth + Deepest Depth) / 2. For the example, (3 ft + 6 ft) / 2 = 4.5 ft.

faq.question: How many gallons are in one cubic foot?
faq.answer: One cubic foot (ft³) holds approximately 7.48052 US gallons of water.

faq.question: Why is pool volume important?
faq.answer: Knowing your pool's volume is crucial for accurate chemical dosing, determining pump and filter sizes, calculating heating costs, and understanding the total water capacity for refilling or repairs.
